reviewText: I like Luke Perry, when he's playing good, he's good, and when he's playing bad, he's bad.  C.Thomas is a good bad guy, I just like the movie.

This is a great story about a retiring sheriff who accidently shoots an innocent man in a saloon. The movie brings forth many good values and the leading lady is beautiful and virtuous. If there was anything I could add it would be a sequel!

I first saw this on TV and liked it. I love the beautiful settings in this western, and the scenery which is different from most. Best of all, I like Luke Perry and his acting. He has a handsome, rugged face, which has the capacity to look kind when needed, and positively hard and calculating when called for. That is an unusual quality and what adds to his acting ability. It is pretty much predictable, for which I would normally only give three stars, but the whole together, for me, makes it a four star film. If you are looking for a western with a difference, this isn't it, but if you are a fan of westerns, this one is great.
I enjoyed this movie as I'm a fan of Luke Perry.  It's a surprisingly good Western, but not one that got recognition.  Worth buying!
Excellent product, as always exceptional service.  Received quickly and as advertized.  Great Movie if you are a Western fan.

Westerns are the Greek Tragedies of the movie world. Well done, they are human, gritty works of art. Done poorly, they can be melodrama. It is fortunate that there are enough of us left who remember the Westerns from the 50s and 60s and can work the formulas correctly. This is one of the good ones.

Matt Austin (Luke Perry) is an ex-sheriff in a town in Texas who has hung up his guns to live a peaceful life with his wife and son on his ranch. Unfortunately, he has some unfinished business who has just escaped from prison, in the person of Tate, whose brother Austin killed a few years before. Austin hears that Tate is loose; but in going looking for him, he is outthunk by Tate, who goes directly to Austin's ranch and murders Austin's family, and escapes again. Austin, decimated, dedicates his life to finding Tate and making him answer for his crimes.

The scene shifts to California, to a town run by an Oil Can Harry of a bad guy (C. Thomas Howell) named Mr. Horn. Mr Horn is trying to run a local Mexicano family off their land, where they have lived for 90 years, because they have something he wants; a bountiful spring, the major source of water in the area. Mr. Horn knows that if he controls the water, he will become the most powerful man in the area. He also knows he has a limited time to pull off his claim to the land; the tax assessors are on their way, and when they come, his claim will be negated. And, of course, he is encountering stiff opposition from the family, composed of a brother Eddie and his widowed sister and her boy. Mr Horn is getting very pushy.

As a last resort, Eddie - against his sister's wishes - rides to a nearby cesspit of a town full of roughnecks and gunmen to hire help in protecting their land. He has the misfortune to be hiring Tate, who has made it to this ugly little town, at the same time as Austin gets there, having tracked Tate to the place. In the gunbattle that ensues, Eddie is killed and Tate gets away. A man of honour, Austin brings Eddie back to his sister and his land.

Amaya, the sister, to her credit understands that the death was accidental, and accepts Austin's offer of help as small recompense for the loss of her brother. Of course, word gets around, and Mr Horn learns of the new hand on the Aguilar ranch. He turns up the heat with hired guns, which inevitably includes - you guessed it - Tate, who has his own agenda.

There is nothing here that hasn't been done many times before, but if it is acted well, it is worth seeing again a new way. Everyone here does their part admirably; Luke Perry is getting the Old West man-of-moral-fiber thing down, and even bears very slight resemblance to a young Clint Eastwood (no rocks thrown, please, I know I'm toying with an icon). C. Thomas Howell, as Mr Horn, is well done, all angular and black-clad and mean; Kim Coates, as Tate, plays a perfect slimeball; and Jaclyn DeSantis, as Amaya, portrays a strong woman of the Old West, determined not to lose her land.

This wasn't "Shane", but it wasn't bad. They're turning out good Westerns these days sometimes; and this one is pretty good. Strongly acted, with good dialog, and believable. The score was good, a little overpowering at times, but it fit the movie. This movie will satisfy your Western fix.

The Spanish land grants were raided by the early eastern Americans
in the 1850's. In this story an family  Rancho is being laid siege
by the local big land owner. First the brother is killed while trying to
recruit 'pistoleros' in a border town by a sheriff hunting the killers of his wife and child. He comes to the rancho and the sister and her son
remind him of his own lost family.
He and a few other good men make a stand.
In this one case the land is held, but in too many historical cases,
in the western states that wasn't the actual case?!
Good movie.
Excellent western movie!  I recommend it to anyone who has fond memories of old-fashioned western movies with an excellent story line.

Not worth renting. Very disappointed by all the good reviews. I wonder if the ratings were reviewed by cast or others involved in the making of this movie. I guess they don't make a good western anymore. Isn't there anyone who can fill Clint Eastwood's shoes?
This movie failed on nearly every level.
great film
Enjoyed Luke Perry in all his westerns.
great
Great movie

As another good Luke Perry movie I am happy to add this one to my collection.  Westerns are one of my favorite genres and this one fits in well.
The movie arrived in a timely manner and in new condition.
great
Great movie!
wonderful
Great movies, we like & watch often.
another great western to enjoy I have all of Luke Perry's movies to watch over many times thanks for good westerns

I had to give it less than it deserves to help counter the inflated judgments of some of the other reviewers.  It was a well done western in many respects but as far as the ending goes it just left me going "WHAT?"  The really evil mastermind of the movie just evaporates at the end and leaves the viewer scratching their heads!  After all the killing he has been responsible for he calls off his gun hands and is all worried about the health of the ranch owner he wanted dead?  And what?  He gets a pass for all the things he already did??  DUMB STUPID ending.  The ONLY way it could have made sense is if it was intended originally as a pilot for a TV series because there was no real resolution!  Not even for the romantic tension that may or may not have been...an unsatisfying, head scratching end...it was like it's writer just could not decide how it should go ...maybe had trouble deciding how to make moral statements over an entertaining movie and so rather failed at both?  Except for the pleasure of the western ambiance it was a DUD film I think.  Not at all worthy of the 4 and 5 stars I see folks giving it!  REALLY?  REALLY?
This is a good moral movie that the whole family can watch together. I would recommend this movie to you as well.

The main reason I picked this movies is because I like Luke Perry. It's a wonderful western and I'm sure all ages would enjoy this one. I've never seen a movie that Luke Perry was in that I didn't like. He's wonderful.

Mary
I have all the Good Night for Justice movies with Luke Perry so I didn't know if this would be a good movie but it is. Love it.
Considering this was a newer movie, I was impressed with all aspects. If you like westerns you will enjoy this one. Watch it!
For anyone who liked the Goodnight series, here is another movie you should love.  He makes his character very believable and the story line could be set to modern times.
Loved it, no problems I will be telling friends about my experience. The price was worth it . Mailed in timely manor.

Don't waste your money buying this or your time watching it.  There wasn't a single moment during my viewing of this made for tv movie that I wasn't acutely aware of the poor acting, writing and production of it.  A good western must have a sense of the outdoors and the characters should seem like they really do live in the old west. This movie has neither.

This is one of the better westerns you'll find, period.  Great performances by Luke Perry as Sheriff Austin, C. Thomas Howell as the land baron possessed by greed, and Kim Coates as Tate, all around low life gunslinger and murderer (you'll recognize him from a similar role in Open Range).

The theme is a common one in the western genre told from a slightly different angle this time, Sheriff Austin (Perry) while out hunting escaped criminals, looses his wife and son, killed by those very criminals.  He quits as sheriff and goes on the hunt for revenge, accidentally killing an innocent man.  Out of remorse, he must help the family of this man defend against land hungry Lamar Horn (Howell) and his henchmen including bought and paid for town sheriff (not the same town) and including Tate (Coates), the murderer of the Austin family.

Very Good drama and action.  Well told and paced, with logical progression.  The only real complaint is one that is common to almost every film. At times, when normally people would offer a more complete explanation of pertinent things at the moment, for some reasons writers either "save" those explanations for a "later" event or exclude them all together.  But that is common in the film industry.  You will, however, enjoy this one.  You will be happy you added it to your collection.  Incidentally, this is included in a triple feature edition with 2 other good westerns starring Kevin Sorbo, Avenging Angel and Prairie Fever.  Unless you like to have the individual art work/case for each film you can pick up the triple feature at a good value.  Enjoy!
Good Western I keep getting them for my husband as he loves to spend the night just watching westerns even if he has seen them before.  It was shipped fast and he did enjoy watching it.
luke perry is alot more mature looking than the 90210 days and shirtless at times, im in.  good movie, decent budget,  good acting, i recommend this one for the family, or for the ladies. h

I enjoyed this movie it had been shown on tv quite a number of times but I kept missing it. Luke makes a fair fist of being a cowboy type and looks comfortable in his role CThomas is a great baddy and there is glamour to boot with ewo hot looking ladies one who's appearence is to short. If you watch this check out when he first leaves home there are no bed rolls then there are one then there are two then none. With that said I for one enjoyed it and I think most people would.
Al Watts

We enjoyed the movie.  Anything Larry Levinson has his name on
is good and we enjoy Kevin Sorbo's acting.

Luke Perry, he amazed me with his acting, playing a cowboy. I had never seen him in this type of movie. He should do alot more westerns, cause he made me believe he was a lawman back in those days. Not too many men can act, and look western, but he threw this performance out the park. So all you Luke Perry fans, and western movie watchers get this movie, it's super great. All the actors, were so good, that I couldn't stand the bad men, even thou they were playing the parts. You will watch it over, and over time after time. As my  self being a great-grandma, this high stepping granny says you all are missing a great movie.. You won't be disappointed at all, Come on all You Grannys who love to watch all those men in tight blue jeans, and think your 20 again, you will love it......

STOO-WOOO-WOOOO-PID.  CRAPPY STORY LINE, CRAPPY ACTING, CRAPPY PRODUCTION, CRAPPY EVERYTHING.  yes, i'm YELLING.  i can't believe i fell for you people telling me it was good . . .  LAME as it can be.  do NOT waste your time or money.
